title: 1776 Commission - Whitewashing Slavery and Native American Genocide
summary: Trump revived the discredited 1776 Commission via executive order to mandate falsified 'patriotic education' in K-12 schools. Original 2020 report justified slavery as 'more the rule than exception throughout human history' and completely omitted Native American genocide. Commission included zero professional historians specializing in US history. Report dismissed continuing legacy of racism in service of whitewashed narrative. Criticized as propaganda designed to sanitize American atrocities. Now mandated as curriculum despite historians calling it 'sheer absurdity' and 'crime against history.'
keyFacts: January 29, 2025: Trump executive order revived 1776 Commission and mandated 'patriotic education' in schools
Original commission created in 2020 as response to New York Times' 1619 Project about systemic racism
1776 Report justifies slavery: 'more the rule than the exception throughout human history'
Report includes zero mention of Native Americans, prerevolutionary land struggles, or Indigenous genocide
Commission had no historians whose work focuses on US history - drafted without professional historian input
Report dismisses continuing legacy of racism and slavery's impact on modern America
Critics: Nation was 'established and maintained through genocidal extermination of Indigenous peoples'
Report 'seeks to whitewash and fictionalize US history as regards race and slavery'
Minimizes 'huge gap between the Founders' ideals and the horrors of slavery'
Human Rights Watch: 'Trump Administration's Assaults on Black History'
ACLU denounced report; historians called it 'sheer absurdity' and propaganda
Order mandates this falsified history be taught in federally funded K-12 schools
Biden had rescinded the commission in 2021; Trump reinstated it as centerpiece of education policy
